author: vorot93
content:
4488 is both rushed _and_ one of those overcomplicated proposals that change semantics of existing entities.

_If_ we are so willing to heavily bank on tx data for storage, maybe make a new tx type instead, with its own semantics (no execution) and pricing (cheap data)?

author: .vbuterin
content: That's exactly what the sharding proposals are doing; the likely roadmap has a step 1 which has the new data in the final format, but no actual sharding, and then step 2 adds shared validation and increases the block size

author: .vbuterin
content: Honestly, I know this is controversial in crypto but I think we should not be so quick to view "rushed" as necessarily bad. The building IS burning. High fees ARE a de facto liveness failure. Users ARE losing more to high fees than they are to security bugs, which implies that thinking high fees are an issue of equal severity to security bugs, to be patched with wartime measures if necessary until cleaner solutions can pick up the slack, is a very reasonable mindset to have

author: .vbuterin
content: Of course this doesn't imply any particular conclusion wrt any specific EIPs, but it does imply a direction of thought. Maybe that direction of thought could lead to more clever short term compromises!

author: .vbuterin
content: The "new transaction type" approach has the issue that it's much more complex, it's not a 5 line change, neither for the core protocol nor for the rollup devs. So if we do that, we need to make the new txs be in the format that they will be in for sharding, so we at least push the rollup teams through the effort of updating once instead of twice

author: .vbuterin
content: And I do think we are not that far away from having exactly such a proposal

author: .vbuterin
content: Though even still, it's far from a 4488 in terms of ease of implementation
